item.title: Finland Clears Last Hurdle to Join NATO, Reshaping Balance of Power
item.description: Turkey’s Parliament approved Finland’s bid to join NATO, its final hurdle to membership in the military alliance. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: In Arrest of US Reporter, Russia Doubles Down on Isolation From West
item.description: The Kremlin, which accused a Wall Street Journal correspondent of being a spy, made a move not seen since the Cold War, further raising the barriers between Russia and the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media of President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday. The Kremlin left little doubt that Mr. Putin had personally approved the arrest of a Wall Street Journal journalist.

item.title: Under the Taliban, Afghanistan Is Trying to Make Due With Less
item.description: In a time of famine and money shortages, meals are a rallying point — and a topic of worry — during a season of change in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amanullah, the pulao master at a popular restaurant in Kabul, preparing to serve the morning’s first customers last month. Since the Taliban took over, what people eat has changed.

item.title: Days After Netanyahu Fired Him, Israel’s Defense Minister Is Still on the Job
item.description: Yoav Gallant, Israel’s defense minister, was fired on Sunday, setting off unrest, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu never formally confirmed his dismissal.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant, the Israeli defense minister, was fired on Sunday but has remained in his post because he did not receive a notification letter.

item.title: At Least 35 Are Killed in India When a Temple’s Well Cover Collapses
item.description: Rescuers struggled to reach other Hindu worshipers who were trapped and injured in a packed temple in Indore during a religious festival.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: An accident victim was carried toward an ambulance at the site of the disaster on Thursday in Indore, India.

item.title: Vatican Repudiates ‘Doctrine of Discovery,’ Used as Justification for Colonization
item.description: Indigenous communities have long called on the Vatican rescind the concept, which had been used over the centuries to seize land from people in the Americas, Africa and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Conference of Catholic Bishops
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis meeting with Indigenous leaders during his trip in Canada, last year.

item.title: Macron, Trying to Move Past Pension Fury, Announces Water Plan
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France presented conservation proposals after an exceptionally dry winter. But his government is still dogged by pension protests.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Savines-le-Lac on Thursday.

item.title: Bankers Are Convicted of Allowing a Putin Ally to Deposit Millions in Swiss Accounts
item.description: The accounts were opened in the name of Sergei P. Roldugin, a concert cellist nicknamed “Putin’s wallet.”
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Outside a court in Zurich this month during the Gazprombank case.

item.title: Police Missteps Contributed to Canada’s Deadliest Shooting Rampage, Inquiry Says
item.description: A commission found there was confusion, poor communication and inflexible thinking among the police during a 13-hour rampage in 2020 in which 23 people died.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Andrew Vaughan/The Canadian Press via AP
item.media:description: A memorial service for an officer killed in the line of duty during a mass shooting in April 2020 in rural Nova Scotia. A commission investigating the killings found a litany of missteps that contributed to the death toll.

item.title: Russia Detains Wall Street Journal Reporter, Accusing Him of Espionage
item.description: The newspaper said it “vehemently denies the allegations” against Evan Gershkovich, an American, and the White House called his detention “unacceptable.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Mr. Gershkovich has worked for The Journal in Moscow since January 2022.

item.title: Bolsonaro Returns to Brazil, Ending Self-Imposed Exile
item.description: The former president returned to a tense political landscape in which he is under investigation for spreading election misinformation and for inspiring the Jan. 8 attack in the capital.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former president of Brazil, waving to supporters outside the Liberal Party’s headquarters in Brasília on Thursday.

item.title: Why This Colombian Town Still Celebrates Christmas in February
item.description: The Afro-Colombian residents of Quinamayó have followed a unique tradition: celebrating Christmas 40 days after the traditional date, a custom begun under the subjugation of slavery.
item.dc:creator: Jaír F. Coll and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Dancing during Christmas celebrations in Quinamayó, Colombia, last month.

item.title: Pope ‘Gradually Improving’ After First Night in the Hospital
item.description: Few details were available about the condition of Pope Francis, 86, and it was too early to determine whether he would be able to attend several Easter-related ceremonies.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Francis was helped to a car after a weekly audience in St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday. He was later taken to a hospital for treatment for a respiratory infection, the Vatican said.

item.title: Ukrainians in a Hidden Command Post See Bakhmut Going Their Way
item.description: Ukrainian commanders said that Russia exhausted all its reserves on the eastern city, though soldiers said the cost in lives had been steep.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: The military operations of a major Ukrainian battle group defending the city of Bakhmut from an unnamed location in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump was indicted.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Donald Trump has created an aura of legal invincibility that the indictment threatens to puncture.

item.title: Turkey Approves Finland’s NATO Membership, a Defeat for Putin
item.description: Finland’s entry into the military alliance after Turkey formally signed off is a significant defeat for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto of Finland and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey met in Ankara earlier this month.

item.title: In Berlin, King Charles Lauds Germany’s Support for Ukraine
item.description: “Together we must be vigilant against threats to our values,” the British monarch said to German lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III of Britain, front center, after delivering a speech at the Bundestag in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: Five Arrested in Migration Center Fire That Left 39 Dead in Mexico
item.description: The authorities said arrest warrants had been obtained for three government migration officials, two private security workers and a migrant accused of starting the blaze.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asylum-seeking migrants, mostly from Venezuela, crossing the Rio Grande into the United States on Wednesday, two days after at least 39 migrants died in a fire at a detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

item.title: 6 U.S. Service Members Suffered Traumatic Brain Injuries in Syria Attacks
item.description: The Pentagon said the injuries were diagnosed during routine screenings in the days after the strikes by Iranian-backed militants.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Patrick S. Ryder, the Pentagon spokesman, said eight militants were killed in a retaliatory U.S. airstrike in Syria last week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Trump Indicted
item.description: Also, an American journalist arrested in Russia and a Chinese billionaire’s downfall.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter
item.media:description: The indictment kicks off a new and volatile phase in Donald Trump’s post-presidential life.

item.title: Kushner Firm Got Hundreds of Millions From 2 Persian Gulf Nations
item.description: The infusion of money from interests in the two Persian Gulf monarchies reflects the close ties to Middle Eastern countries established by Jared Kushner, former President Donald Trump’s son-in-law.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Swan, Kate Kelly, Maggie Haberman and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner attending the Future Investment Initiative conference in Saudi Arabia last year. Mr. Kushner’s private equity firm has received investments from Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: U.S. Puts Sanctions on Man Accused of Working on Russia-North Korea Arms Deal
item.description: A White House spokesman said the man would be in violation of several U.N. Security Council resolutions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

item.title: A.I., Brain Scans and Cameras: The Spread of Police Surveillance Tech
item.description: In the Middle East, artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies have become part of everyday policing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Dubai’s police run next-generation surveillance systems from a headquarters north of the city’s downtown skyscrapers and malls.

item.title: Studies Link Common Childhood Viruses to Rare Hepatitis Cases
item.description: Infection with multiple common viruses may be responsible for the cases that puzzled doctors last year.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Sailboat Crew Rescued After Hitting Whale in Pacific Ocean
item.description: After the collision in the Pacific Ocean this month, Rick Rodriguez and three other sailors were rescued by a fellow boater, with an assist from a satellite internet signal.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: A Mexican Grandmother Finds the Right Recipe for Culinary Stardom
item.description: Through her YouTube videos, Doña Ángela has become among the most watched and beloved cooks in the crowded market of online food shows. But what explains her widespread popularity?
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: De Mi Rancho a Tu Cocina (YouTube Channel)
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bradley Coss and his mother, Cruz Ortiz, watch Doña Ángela’s YouTube cooking videos from their home in El Paso. “You can see in my mom the genuine joy it brings her to watch those videos.” Mr. Coss said.

item.title: The Biggest Battle in Ukraine
item.description: Why Russia and Ukraine are fighting for a city with little strategic value.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Ukrainian military on the street of Bakhmut in December 2022.

item.title: Ukraine Goes Dark: NASA Images Drive Home a Nation’s Anguish
item.description: A satellite operated by NASA and NOAA bares how Russia’s drones and missiles knocked out the nation’s power.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad, Sarah Kerr, Marc Santora and Tim Wallace
item.media:credit: NASA Black Marble Team, Goddard Space Flight Center

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Fears grow about Ukraine’s imperiled nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A team from the International Atomic Energy Agency visited the plant yesterday.

item.title: Philippines Ferry Fire Kills at Least 28
item.description: The vessel caught fire near the southern island province of Basilan, the coast guard said. The cause of the accident was under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
item.media:description: A Philippine Coast Guard vessel was deployed to fight the fire on Wednesday night.

item.title: Mexico Investigates Migrant Center Fire Deaths as Homicide Case
item.description: The authorities identified eight suspects and said government workers and private security workers had done nothing to help migrants flee the blaze at a detention center in Ciudad Juárez.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Natalie Kitroeff and Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants spent the night outside of a detention center where at least 38 people died in a fire this week in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

item.title: Biden’s Confrontation With Netanyahu Had Been Brewing for Years
item.description: The president’s decision to publicly criticize Israel is highly unusual for a leader who has pledged not to interfere in the country’s domestic politics.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Proposed changes to Israel’s judiciary have divided the country and ignited huge protests.

item.title: Soldiers Massing Near Ukrainian Nuclear Plant, U.N. Official Warns
item.description: Amid signs of offensives and counteroffensives, concern is rekindling about what it will mean for the biggest nuclear plant in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant as seen from the city of Nikopol in 2022.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers a Mercenary’s Confession and the Confrontation Clause
item.description: In the case of a murder in the Philippines, the justices weighed whether relaying a confession that implicated another crossed a constitutional line.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justices of the Supreme Court heard arguments in a case stemming from a murder for hire in the Philippines in 2012.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: How Modi Wields Power
item.description: Also, a plea for a pause on A.I. and a U.N. resolution on climate lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi said that those who had accused him of subverting India’s institutions were engaged in a “conspiracy” intended to “finish off the credibility” of those institutions.

item.title: Putin’s top security adviser holds talks with India’s prime minister as Moscow seeks closer ties.
item.description: The Russian envoy was accompanied by a Russian oil executive, who signed new deals with India.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir, Ivan Nechepurenko and James C. McKinley Jr.

item.title: Modi Tightens Grip on India’s Democracy, Wielding the Judiciary
item.description: The ouster from Parliament of India’s best-known opposition leader shows how Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party is manipulating the judiciary, critics say.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: The Congress party leader, Rahul Gandhi, in New Delhi on Saturday after his disqualification as a member of Parliament.

item.title: Amsterdam Has a Message for Male British Tourists: ‘Stay Away’
item.description: In an ad campaign aimed at British men between 18 and 35, the Dutch capital threatens fines for visitors who are looking for a “messy night.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign from Amsterdam is aimed at “nuisance tourists” who are planning to “go nuts,” according to the city’s announcement.

item.title: Israeli Crisis Shows How Protests Can, and Can’t, Force Change
item.description: What does it take for a mass movement to translate public anger into political results? Leverage.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against the Israeli government’s proposed judicial overhaul outside Parliament on Monday.

item.title: How Anti-Israel Protests Cost Indonesia a FIFA Soccer Championship
item.description: Preparations for the tournament were thrown into disarray when a governor asked Indonesia’s sports ministry to bar Israel’s team from participating.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Victor Mather
item.media:description: Banners for the Indonesia 2023 FIFA Under-20 World Cup football tournament in Jakarta on Thursday.

item.title: AstraZeneca’s Covid Vaccine May Have Posed a Higher Heart Risk for Young Women, Study Shows
item.description: A new analysis examined deaths in Britain, where the company’s product was restricted in 2021 because of safety concerns.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Preparing a dose of the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine at a temporary site in the City Hall of Hull in northeast England.

item.title: Yang Bing-yi, Founder of Dumpling Empire Din Tai Fung, Dies at 96
item.description: Starting with a modest shop in Taiwan in 1958, he built Din Tai Fung into a global dumpling and noodle empire, earning a Michelin star along the way.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.category: Din Tai Fung Management and Consulting LLC

item.title: Pope Francis Hospitalized for Respiratory Infection
item.description: The Vatican said the 86-year-old pontiff was taken to a hospital in Rome, where he was being treated for a respiratory infection.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis blessing guests during his weekly general audience in St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday morning.

item.title: Even as U.S. Beckons, European Leaders Head to Beijing
item.description: China is trying to improve relations with the European Union just as the United States is pushing the bloc to pick sides.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, fourth chair on the right side, met with China’s premier, Li Keqiang, fifth chair on the left, in November in Beijing.

item.title: Vanuatu Strikes a Blow for Climate Justice
item.description: Vanuatu, a disaster-prone Pacific country, has secured United Nations approval to take that question to the International Court of Justice.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Damage from cyclone Kevin in Port Villa, Vanuatu, this month, in an image taken from social media video.

item.title: DNA Confirms Oral History of Swahili People
item.description: A genetic analysis of dozens of ancient skeletons from East Africa helps pin down the origins of coastal Swahili society.
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin
item.media:description: The ruins of Gede, a medieval Swahili coastal settlement in Kenya where researchers are now searching for the remains of less well-to-do Swahili people.

item.title: King Charles Arrives in Germany for First State Visit as Monarch
item.description: Charles and Camilla, the queen consort, visited the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin to start their three-day trip.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Jenny Gross
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III and Camilla, the queen consort, standing with President Frank-Walter Steinmeier of Germany and his wife, Elke Büdenbender, at the Brandenburg Gate on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Will Use Legal Means to Evict Orthodox Pro-Russia Monks
item.description: Representatives of the monks and priests have vowed to ignore an eviction order.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Priests and monks loaded cars and trucks before a threatened government eviction at the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra monastery on Tuesday.

item.title: Obamacare Keeps Winning
item.description: Its North Carolina victory is a sign of larger changes.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Eamon Queeney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Governor Roy Cooper during a bill signing to expand Medicaid coverage in Raleigh on Monday.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Battered Steel Industry Galvanized Its War Effort
item.description: Ukraine’s iron- and steel-producing factories have made body armor, helmets and armored plates for vehicles — and steelworkers risked their lives rolling out heavy machinery at the beginning of the war to help physically block the Russian advance.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: The Yankees Cap Goes Viral in Brazil: ‘Is It Basketball?’
item.description: The New York Yankees logo is everywhere in Brazil. What it means, however, is up for interpretation.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A large selection of counterfeit Yankees caps on display at a stand in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: The Incredible Challenge of Counting Every Global Birth and Death
item.description: In rural Colombia, as in many parts of the world, tallying births and deaths is one of the most desperately needed public-health measures. It’s a lot harder than it sounds.
item.dc:creator: Jeneen Interlandi
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Diana Hidalgo, left, and Dr. Paola Rosero delivering a newborn girl in Mocoa, Colombia.

item.title: U.S.-Israel Tensions Over Judicial Overhaul Burst Into Open
item.description: In response to sharp criticism by President Biden, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that Israel would make its own decisions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amid tensions with Israel, President Biden told reporters that he was “very concerned” about the events there.

item.title: Taiwan’s President Heads to the U.S., Bracing for China’s Retaliation
item.description: President Tsai Ing-wen is expected to meet Speaker Kevin McCarthy next week, risking a show of force from Beijing, which opposes any such exchanges.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Chris Horton
item.category: German Marshall Fund of the United States
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan. She has sought to promote Taiwan’s position as a thriving democracy in Asia and shore up its security and economic ties with the United States.

item.title: The head of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog arrives at Ukraine’s embattled Zaporizhzhia plant.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, after visiting the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in September.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia bombards a town near Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Gennadiy Yudin, a police officer, trying to persuade an Avdiivka resident to evacuate on Monday.

item.title: Junta Disbands Aung San Suu Kyi’s Political Party in Myanmar
item.description: The regime has dissolved dozens of opposition parties ahead of the next general election, including the popular National League for Democracy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A flag of the National League for Democracy in Yangon, Myanmar, on Feb. 1, 2021, when the military seized power.

item.title: Some Ukrainians Refuse to Leave Avdiivka Despite Russian Bombardment
item.description: In Avdiivka, as in Bakhmut and other devastated places on the front lines, most residents left long ago, but there are holdouts.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak
item.media:description: Collecting wood in Avdiivka, Ukraine, this month. In the last few weeks, Russia has intensified its bombardment of Avdiivka and outlying villages.

item.title: Kamala Harris, at Former Slave Port in Ghana, Ties Past to Present
item.description: The vice president leaned into her heritage during a three-nation trip to Africa to strengthen U.S. relations on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: “This continent, of course, has a special significance for me personally, as the first Black vice president,” Ms. Harris said.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China’s Billions in Bailouts
item.description: Also, a shake-up at Alibaba and a rare glimpse at a ruined city in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sri Lanka, which received financing from China for construction in Colombo in 2018, is among the debt-ridden countries receiving emergency loans from Beijing.
